awd_titl_txt: Sulfur(VI) Fluoride Exchange (SuFEx) Click Chemistry in Macromolecule Synthesis and Fabrication
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are very useful materials in our daily life.  Polymers are made by chemically connecting the building blocks into very large structures similar to a child using Legos to construct and create a building.  This research project focuses on developing reactions that connect the polymer building blocks in a highly efficient manner. under mild reaction conditions.  Another important goal of this project is to increase the participation of women, underrepresented minorities, K-12 students, and undergraduates in educational programs across the San Diego community. This project involves elementary school students through a click chemistry lecture / demonstration at the Elementary Institute of Science.  It also involves local high school students through the High School Research Education Program. Additionally, the project provides opportunities for community college students to work on the development of click chemistry through a new curriculum designed for the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellows (SURF) Program at The Scripps Research Institute.

SuFEx chemistry is a useful click reaction recently developed to construct structurally-diversified materials with desired properties. Sulfonyl/sulfuryl fluorides possess a combination of synthetic accessibility, stability, and responsiveness to the presentation of proton or silyl activators - molecular cofactors that enhance reactivity in subtle, yet powerful, ways.  The goal of this project is to explore the feasibility of using SuFEx click chemistry to fabricate polymeric and dendritic materials with diverse chemical structures. There are three objectives in this project. The first objective is to search for better catalysts to promote SuFEx-based transformations requiring lower catalyst loading and milder reaction conditions. The second objective is to synthesize and functionalize polymeric materials using SuFEx click chemistry developed under the first objective. The third objective is to prepare dendritic materials based on SuFEx click chemistry. Through these studies, this research seeks to understand the strengths and limitations of SuFEx in the construction of macromolecular, supramolecular and nanoscopic materials, and to establish modular reactions to build these molecules.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polymers are very useful materials in our daily life. Polymers are manufactured by chemically connecting the building blocks into very large structures similar to a child using Legos to construct and create a building. In this project, we have focused on developing connective reactions for the construction of polymeric and dendritic materials with diverse chemical structures in a highly efficient manner under mild reaction conditions. Sulfur(VI) fluoride exchange (SuFEx) chemistry was developed in our lab as another excellent click reaction to construct structurally diversified materials with desired properties.  We used reagents containing S(VI)-F as versatile connectors. Moreover, we have successfully developed novel bifluoride catalysts that could promote the polycondensation reactions with remarkably improved efficiency and milder reaction conditions, which is essential for cost-effective industrial scale production. We have applied this methodology in the preparation of a kilogram scale of polysulfates and polysulfonates. This process was practical with respect to high molecular weight, to reduced catalyst cost, polymer purification and by-product recycling. In addition, we have extended the set of SVI connectors for polymer synthesis. For instance, multidimensional S(VI)-F functionalization has been achieved using thionyl fluoride gas as the connector. The unique feature of these derivatives provides opportunities for click chemistry to be applied to the fabrication of new types of 3D-polymers. We also designed chain growth polymers by using this connector in which we achieved exact control of the molecular weight of polymers. Furthermore, these polymers made by this new method possessed degradable properties under basic conditions and at different temperatures. The plastic crisis is one of the greatest challenges facing our planet today. Degradable polymeric materials may provide a nice solution to this challenge and afford sustainability, recyclability, and environmental responsibility.

This project involved the training of students in organic synthesis and polymer characterization. Students learned polymer chemistry and fluorine chemistry directed toward catalyst design and SuFEx polycondensation reactions under the guidance of the PI. The students also had the opportunity to present their work at meetings and attend numerous seminars. The PI also provided the students with strategic advice regarding job searches and future career plans. 

The broader impact of the project was to increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields and to improve the scientific literacy of the public at large. Our lab hosted a group of students from the California State University San Marcos Bridges Program for education outreach. We intended to prepare students from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups for professional research careers in the biomedical sciences. In addition, we hosted students from China (Zhejiang University of Technology). These students were very motivated young scholars who wanted to pursue graduate school and eventually a career in biotech and pharmaceutical industry. Our graduate students and post-doctoral associates gave demonstrations of SuFEx polymerization to the visiting students and an overview of the powerful research that is being conducted our lab.


Last Modified: 11/12/2021
Modified by: K. Barry Sharpless
